channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: This Working Man Was Ready to Retire. But the Coronavirus Took Him.
item.description: A journey down several blocks of one Pennsylvania city tells the story of the virus in America — of illness, financial strain and rising tension.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: North Wyoming Street in Hazleton, Pa., on April 18. Five days along a few blocks of old, worn rowhouses and storefronts here revealed the virus to be all around.

item.title: Georgia Prosecutor Will Bring Shooting of Ahmaud Arbery to Grand Jury
item.description: Mr. Arbery, 25, was killed after a confrontation with two white men who pursued him in a South Georgia neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset

item.title: Coronavirus in the U.S.: An Unrelenting Crush of Cases and Deaths
item.description: While cities like New York have seen a hopeful drop in cases, upticks in other major cities and smaller communities have offset those decreases.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith and Amy Harmon
item.media:description: A neighborhood in New York City, which has seen a drop in new cases of the coronavirus.

item.title: Money for Welfare Instead Funded Concerts, Lobbyists and Football Games, Audit Finds
item.description: According to a state audit, Mississippi allowed tens of millions of dollars in federal anti-poverty funds to be used in ways that did little or nothing to help the poor.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.category: Davis, John (Mississippi Department of Human Services)
item.media:description: Shad White, the Mississippi state auditor, right, and Hinds County District Attorney Jody Owens discuss the auditor’s office investigation about millions in federal money meant for the poor, in February in Jackson, Miss.

item.title: Ji Chaozhu, Interpreter for China During Nixon’s Trip, Dies at 90
item.description: With his flawless English, he sometimes translated for both American and Chinese officials, making him the “indispensable man.”
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:credit: Ryan Pyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ji Chaozhu in 2012 near his home in China, on the southern island of Hainan. “When the Korean War broke out, I was torn between my love for two countries,” Mr. Ji once said. “But I knew I was fundamentally Chinese.”

item.title: King County in Washington Agrees to $2.25 Million Settlement in Teen’s Shooting
item.description: MiChance Dunlap-Gittens was fatally shot by officers during an undercover operation in 2017. The settlement includes a promise to pursue a policy requiring dashboard and body cameras.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: A $5 Billion Proposal to Fight Online Child Sexual Abuse
item.description: New legislation would try to curb the illegal imagery with record levels of funding for law enforcement. The bill, coming in response to a Times investigation, also calls for a new oversight position in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller
item.category: National Center for Missing and Exploited Children
item.media:credit: Kholood Eid for The New York Times
item.media:description: A phone was analyzed for child abuse material last year after a raid on a suspect’s home.

item.title: Herd Immunity, or Big 2nd Wave? Israel Antibody Testing Hopes to Find Out
item.description: Blood tests of 100,000 Israelis will try to assess exposure to Covid-19 on a nationwide scale.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Monday, Israel announced that citizens could leave their homes after a 40-day lockdown, but many aspects of economic and social life remain curtailed.

item.title: This Food Delivery Worker Won’t Let Coronavirus Get in Her Way
item.description: D’Shea Grant’s deliveries take longer than they used to. Her customers are on edge. The pandemic has made everything more complicated. But she keeps at it anyway.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg

item.title: First Quarter Earnings Were Terrible, But Executives Offer Some Hope
item.description: While the pandemic has made it hard to offer forecasts, some corporate leaders said things might be getting a little better — or at least no worse.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coronavirus pandemic is hurting many companies, but that didn’t stop some from pointing to some glimmers of hope.

item.title: Coronavirus Concerns Flare Up Again on Stricken Carrier Roosevelt
item.description: For the second time in about a month, the Navy is weighing crew safety against war readiness aboard the Theodore Roosevelt.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, John Ismay, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The possibility of a new outbreak on the carrier Theodore Roosevelt highlights the difficulty of containing the coronavirus and accurately testing for it in a population of about 4,800 sailors.

item.title: Supreme Court Weighs Anti-Prostitution Pledge for AIDS Grants
item.description: In 2013, the Supreme Court said requiring domestic groups to take the pledge violated the First Amendment. The new case concerned their foreign affiliates.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: The Supreme Court heard a case that was a variation of one it had decided in 2013.

item.title: A Wendy’s With No Burgers as Meat Production Is Hit
item.description: Hundreds of the fast-food chain’s locations aren’t serving hamburgers and grocery stores are limiting meat purchases, as shoppers begin to feel the impact of meatpacking plant shutdowns.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Corkery
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Zarina Hashmi, Artist of a World in Search of Home, Dies at 82
item.description: Ms. Hashmi was of a generation of artists whose life and work were haunted by the 1947 partition of India.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter

item.title: Irish Return an Old Favor, Helping Native Americans Battling the Virus
item.description: In 1847 the Choctaw people sent $170 to help during the potato famine. Irish donors are citing that gesture as they help two tribes during the Covid-19 pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin and Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: The Kindred Spirits Choctaw Monument art installation in Midleton, Ireland, commemorating the Choctaw donation during the potato famine.

item.title: Judge Justin Walker Faces Scrutiny in Bid for Seat on Powerful Appeals Court
item.description: No stranger to partisan warfare at 37, Judge Justin Walker will go before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is considering him for a seat on the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:description: Judge Justin Walker is a nominee for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, long seen as a potential springboard to the Supreme Court.

item.title: How Small Physician Practices are Struggling to Survive During Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: As visits plummet because of the coronavirus, small physician practices are struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.media:credit: Houston Cofield for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Autumn Road Family Practice in Little Rock, Ark., has seen a steep decline in the number of patients but is offering free drive-up testing for the coronavirus.

item.title: 5-Year-Old From Utah Caught Driving to California on Highway
item.description: The boy was driving to California to buy a Lamborghini, the Utah Highway Patrol said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: When he approached the driver’s side window on Monday, the trooper was surprised by what he saw: a young boy wearing a gray Utah Royals soccer hoodie.

item.title: New Studies Add to Evidence that Children May Transmit the Coronavirus
item.description: Experts said the new data suggest that cases could soar in many U.S. communities if schools reopen soon.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Workers sprayed disinfectant at the Saint Exupery primary school in Cannes, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Rural America’s Digital Divide Persists
item.description: The pandemic is making clear that rural Americans are left behind. Less clear is how to fix it.
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: Working From Home Has Benefits Some Don't Want to Lose
item.description: Millions of Americans are taking part in an unprecedented experiment in working from home. Many are happier, more efficient and want to hang onto the benefits when the pandemic ends.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: Jacquie Benetua-Rolens working at home in her yard.

item.title: With Crispr, a Possible Quick Test for the Coronavirus
item.description: A pioneer of the gene-editing technology has devised a diagnostic test for the infection that could be as simple as a pregnancy test.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Scientists say it remains to be seen how the Crispr technique compares to the standard tests now in use, known as polymerase chain reaction, or PCR, shown here.

item.title: Adam Neumann, WeWork’s Former Chief, Sues SoftBank
item.description: The lawsuit accuses SoftBank of improperly backing out of an offer to buy shares held by Mr. Neumann, employees and other investors.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:description: Adam Neumann’s lawsuit claims that SoftBank “was secretly taking actions to undermine” the deal.

item.title: What Is Phase 2 of Reopening California? Some Businesses Can Reopen Friday.
item.description: Tuesday: Here’s what we know about the soon-to-be-relaxed stay-at-home order. Also: the state’s economy; and virtual tourism.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A women arriving to prepare meals to hand out to children at the Y.W.C.A. in San Fernando.

item.title: On Politics: What Reopening Really Means
item.description: A grim government projection as deaths rise and economies restart: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Pfizer Begins Human Trials of Possible Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: The drug company, along with a German partner, is running tests in healthy volunteers. It’s one of several companies on an accelerated timetable to try to find a safe, effective vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:description: A volunteer taking part in a human trial of a potential vaccine for the coronavirus. Nearly a dozen groups have started testing potential vaccines in human trials.

item.title: Coronavirus, Don Shula, J. Crew: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates
item.description: An ousted federal scientist said he was pressured to steer contracts to clients of a well-connected consultant. More than 1,000 people have died each day for over a month. Meat is scarcer at groceries and restaurants.

item.title: Republican Senate Panel Signals Support for John Ratcliffe as Intelligence Chief
item.description: His confirmation hearing was the first to employ social distancing rules for senators since the coronavirus pandemic took hold.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative John Ratcliffe, Republican of Texas, was sworn into his confirmation hearing on Tuesday. Senators were spaced apart to comply with social distancing guidelines, and no audience was allowed in the hearing.

item.title: Coronavirus Exposes a G.O.P. Divide: Is the Market Always Supreme?
item.description: A growing push by lawmakers and policy experts on the right is challenging some of the small-government, free-market tenets at the heart of the Republican Party’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio argues that the coronavirus has revealed the nation’s need to be more aggressive and innovative with its laws so it can better protect itself from adversarial powers like China.

item.title: A Bitter Battle for a California House Seat Unfolds in Quarantine
item.description: A special election offers a preview of November: President Trump has waded in. Uncertainty surrounds vote-by-mail. Doubts have been sown about the election’s integrity.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christy Smith, a Democrat, in Los Angeles in November. She and her Republican opponent, Mike Garcia, are vying to represent California’s 25th Congressional District.

item.title: How to Talk About Coronavirus
item.description: Pandemic-related terms have permeated everyday speech, yielding dictionary updates and slangified phrases. But what about after coronavirus?
item.dc:creator: Kate Mooney

item.title: Faces, Faces Everywhere
item.description: In this Covid-19 spring, a socially hungry person is inclined to see faces where there are none.
item.dc:creator: George Etheredge and Benedict Carey
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times

item.title: Self-Isolated at the End of the World
item.description: Alone in the long Antarctic night, Adm. Richard E. Byrd endured the ultimate in social distancing.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: The Thinnest Paper in the World
item.description: The process of making tengujo is fairly simple, but the nearly transparent product that results is almost magical.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: Above, Hiroyoshi Chinzei, the owner and operator of Hidaka Washi, with the world’s thinnest paper.

item.title: Parking Lots Have Become a Digital Lifeline
item.description: With cafes and libraries closed, Americans without internet access are sitting outside them to get free and fast connections.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Jacob Biba for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beth Revis, an author, using the free Wi-Fi outside Mount Vernon-Ruth Elementary School in Rutherfordton, N.C.

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The largest U.S. airlines are averaging just 17 passengers on domestic flights and 29 on international flights, an airline executive said in prepared testimony for a Senate hearing.

item.title: France, India and China Coronavirus Live Coverage
item.description: French doctors found that a patient had the virus on Dec. 27, suggesting that it was circulating long before containment efforts began. Israel is surveying its population to see how widespread infections are.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus case in France in December, in a man who hadn’t traveled for months, implies person-to-person transmission in Europe far earlier than previously known.

item.title: Greg Zanis, Known as 'The Cross Man,' Dies at 69
item.description: Mr. Zanis, a carpenter who traveled the country honoring the dead, made over 26,000 wooden memorials over the past two decades.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Greg Zanis of Aurora, Ill., preparing crosses to place at a makeshift memorial for victims of a mass shooting in El Paso in August.

item.title: A Coronavirus Vaccine Project Takes a Page From Gene Therapy
item.description: The technique aims to make a person’s cells churn out proteins that will stimulate the body to fight the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: As stay-home orders are lifted, the government is privately projecting that America’s daily death toll will reach grim new heights by June.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Most Events in the Lincoln Memorial Are Banned. Trump Got an Exception.
item.description: Citing the “extraordinary crisis” of the coronavirus, the interior secretary relaxed the rules so the president could hold a Fox News interview in one of the nation’s most hallowed spaces.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: “I don’t think it’s ever been done, what we’re doing tonight, here, and I think it’s great for the American people to see,” President Trump told the Fox News interviewers on Sunday.

item.title: Pulitzer Prizes: A Guide to the Winning Books and Finalists
item.description: Here are the 2020 contenders for fiction, nonfiction, poetry, history and biography.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.category: Sweet Taste of Liberty: A True Story of Slavery and Restitution in America (Book)
Race for Profit: How Banks and the Real Estate Industry Undermined Black Homeownership (Book)
The End of the Myth: From the Frontier to the Border Wall in the Mind of America (Book)
Our Man: Richard Holbrooke and the End of the American Century (Book)
The Undying: Pain, Vulnerability, Mortality, Medicine, Art, Time, Dreams, Data, Exhaustion, Cancer, and Care (Book)
Solitary: Unbroken by Four Decades in Solitary Confinement. My Story of Transformation and Hope (Book)
Elderhood: Redefining Aging, Transforming Medicine, Reimagining Life (Book)
Only as the Day Is Long: New and Selected Poems (Book)
